headline: More Whistleblower Complaints Emerge in 737 MAX Probe
summary: Investigators are looking into complaints by roughly a dozen purported whistleblowers alleging safety problems with Boeing’s 737 MAX jets, according to officials familiar with the matter.

headline: Four Dead After Construction Crane Collapses in Seattle
summary: Four people were killed and three injured when a construction crane collapsed Saturday in downtown Seattle, pinning six cars underneath, Seattle’s fire chief said.

headline: New York Attorney General Probes NRA as Oliver North Exits as President
summary: The New York attorney general’s office is investigating potential financial and disclosure problems at the National Rifle Association, amid boardroom turmoil at the group that led Saturday to the departure of NRA President Oliver North after a bruising internal political battle.

headline: Japan’s Shipping Trio Posts Deep Losses After Merging Container Operations
summary: Japanese shipping giant Nippon Yusen Kaisha replaced its top executive after posting a ¥44.5 billion annual loss, indicating its struggle to set up a merged container business with two of its rivals.

headline: France’s Yellow Vests, Unappeased, Are Back to Demanding Change
summary: Thousands of yellow-vest protesters returned to French streets Saturday, a sign that President Emmanuel Macron’s great national debate and a promise to lower taxes haven’t quelled demands for sweeping public-sector reform.

headline: OPEC, Saudi Officials Haven’t Spoken With Trump About Oil Prices
summary: President Trump hasn’t spoken over the phone with the OPEC secretary-general or with the Saudi energy minister in an effort to seek lower oil prices, according to people familiar with the matter. Mr. Trump told reporters he called OPEC.

headline: Sri Lanka Militants Set Off Bombs During Raid, Killing 15
summary: Militants linked to Easter suicide bombings opened fire and set off explosives during a raid by Sri Lankan security forces on a house in the country’s east, leaving 15 bodies, including six children.

headline: For Musicians, Screen Time Is a Growing Source of Income
summary: Licensing music for ads, TV, movies and other visual media—placements known as “sync”—is a growth engine for the recording business and increasingly the way many artists make a living.

headline: This Biotech Is Going to the Dogs
summary: Elanco Animal Health said it would acquire Aratana Therapeutics, a biotech that develops dog and cat medicine, in a stock deal valued at about $234 million. Elanco is going to have to learn some new tricks.

headline: A Lofty Proposition: Capturing a New York Apartment on Stage
summary: A number of the season’s shows, from the revivals of the plays “Burn This,” “Torch Song Trilogy” and “The Waverly Gallery” to the newly unveiled musical “Tootsie” based on the 1982 film, have settings in New York domiciles.

headline: Japan’s New Emperor Picks His Ride—an Old-School Toyota
summary: Crown Prince Naruhito will get more than a new title when he ascends the Japanese throne on May 1. He will also get a new set of wheels—an exclusive, superluxury, handmade Toyota.

headline: Old Dominion Will Continue With Pricing Strategy Despite Competition
summary: The trucking company said some competitors have been going after ODFL’s larger clients in the less-than-truckload market. ODFL executives said the pricing pressures aren’t widespread and that it sees a generally stable pricing environment.

headline: No. 3 at Justice Leaving Post Administration Has Struggled to Fill
summary: The official who has been serving in the Justice Department’s No. 3 job is stepping down as William Barr moves to put his stamp on the department’s leadership team.

headline: Supply Side of the Economy Is Flashing Strength
summary: Signs are emerging that the supply side of the economy—the workers and the tools and machines they use to produce goods—is becoming energized, improving the chances that faster growth can be sustained, writes Jon Hilsenrath.

headline: Parents Can’t Monitor Autistic Son with GPS Tracker at School, Nevada Ruling Says
summary: The parents of an autistic child in Nevada who fought to have his school let him wear a GPS tracker with the ability to listen in on his surroundings lost their battle in a case that could resonate in school districts across the U.S.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Another Stock Market Record, but It’s a Different Kind of Boom
summary: The biggest threat to the recent stock-market rebound is the end of the Goldilocks economy, either through a return to fears of recession, or a resurgence of inflation that wakes the Fed’s hawks from their slumber.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: The FDA Says It’s Safe, So Feel Free to Say ‘Yes’ to MSG
summary: Japan’s Ajinomoto is in the middle of a campaign to persuade Americans that the seasoning it has made for more than a century is safe--and maybe even good for you.

headline: TikTok Is the Latest Reason Teens Are Addicted to Their Phones
summary: The app is perfect for spreading memes, the lingua franca of the web. But good luck deciphering things like the ‘microwave challenge’ if you’re not in on the joke.

headline: A Star Curator Falls in Love With Los Angeles
summary: Klaus Biesenbach, the new director of the Museum of Contemporary Art, talks about exploring Los Angeles and setting a new tone for the institution.

headline: Fashion Houses Try to Kick the Plastic Habit
summary: Cardboard hangers and eco-friendly packaging are coming as fashion houses use less plastic to address shoppers’ concerns about sustainability.

headline: Russian Woman Who Sought U.S.-Russia Backchannel Gets 18-Month Sentence
summary: Maria Butina, the Russian woman who used gun-rights advocacy to establish ties with the National Rifle Association and attempt to influence U.S. policy in favor of the Kremlin, was sentenced to 18 months in prison.

headline: ‘The American Pre-Raphaelites: Radical Realists’ Review: Finding Beauty in the Details
summary: Unlike the Hudson River School, which explored vastness and grandeur, this movement focused on works, usually modest in size, that were candid studies of scenery, frequently wooded, with sun-dappled verdure faithfully recorded down to the veins and textures of every curling leaf and fern.

headline: As Sudan Grapples With a Post-Bashir Future, Regional Powers Circle
summary: In the battle to determine the future of Sudan after the ouster of longtime dictator Omar al-Bashir, two foreign powers closely allied to the U.S. are playing an outsize role: Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.

headline: He Conquered Cancer, Then 15 Spartan Races in a Year
summary: Completing one muddy obstacle-course Trifecta at full strength is hard enough, but this 77-year-old wanted to knock out five.

headline: PG&E’s Radical Plan to Prevent Wildfires: Shut Down the Power Grid
summary: When dangerously high winds arise this year, the utility says it will black out fire-prone areas that are home to 5.4 million people. No U.S. utility has blacked out so many on purpose.

headline: The Real Danger of Going on ‘Shark Tank’ Is Copycats
summary: Entrepreneurs appear on “Shark Tank” to prowl for attention and cash, but they also can end up being prey—for copycats who start selling knockoffs of ideas pitched on the reality TV show.

headline: The Founding Generation Also Had to Fight ‘Anti-Vaxxers’
summary: In the 1720s, Cotton Mather supported an early form of inoculation; Washington, Jefferson and Adams followed suit.
